row.head: Beth ʿAbe, Monastery of
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/223
row.abstract:
This famous monastery was founded in 595/6 by Yaʿqub, a monk of the 'Great Monastery' of Abraham of Kashkar
(on the mountain of Izla), who originated from Lashom in Beth Garmai.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Beth Aramaye

row.abstract: An ecclesiastical province confined between the Lower Zab northward, the Tigris westward, the Diyālā river southward, and the mountains of Ḥimrīn eastward.

row.head: Bible, New Testament manuscripts

row.head: Bibliography

row.abstract: Over the course of some 500 years, from the late 4th to the late 9th cent. an enormous number of Greek texts were translated into Syriac.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Gregory of Nazianzus
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/511
row.abstract: Greek Church Father, and one of the three Cappadocian Fathers, whose influential writings earned him the title 'the theologian'.

row.head: Gregory of Nyssa
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/512
row.abstract: Greek Church Father. One of the three Cappadocian Fathers, and the brother of Basil and Macrina.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Gregory Thaumaturgus
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/513
row.abstract: Greek author (CPG 1763–94). Several of his works were translated into Syriac, the most important of which is a 'Discourse on the Passible and Impassible in God', addressed to Theopompus, whose Greek original is lost (ed. de Lagarde, 46–64; ET in Slusser, 152–73).
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Grigor I
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/514
row.abstract: Cath. since 605. Grigor originated from Prat d-Mayshan.

row.head: Grigorios of Cyprus
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/21
row.abstract: Monastic author. Very little is known of this Persian monk from Susiana, and earlier scholars wrongly identified him as a contemporary of Epiphanius (d. 403), since one of the three monastic letters he wrote is addressed to a disciple of that name.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Grigorios Yawseph
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/281
row.abstract: Minor author, scribe and bp. of Jerusalem (1510/12-1537).

row.head: Guidi, Ignazio
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/517
row.abstract: Italian Syriac scholar. One of the most eminent scholars in the philology of Semitic and Eastern Christian literatures, he taught at the University of Rome from 1876 to 1919.

row.head: Guillaumont, Antoine

row.abstract: Syriac scholar, specialist of Eastern Christian asceticism and monasticism.

row.head: Hakkari

row.abstract: The region in the southeast corner of Turkey dominated by the mountains Cilo Dag (4170 m.) and Sat Dag (3810 m.), and the highlands around them, cut by the gorges of the Great Zab River and its tributaries.

row.head: de Halleux, André

row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/215
row.abstract: City in Syria. Ḥimṣ, known in Syriac as Ḥemṣ, Ḥmeṣ, and Puniqi, and located on a fertile plain just east of the Orontes (ʿĀṣī) river, was in the 1st cent. BC the seat of a local Arab principality, which became a vassal of Rome in 64 BC.

row.head: Ḥimyar
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/474
row.abstract: Himyar is the name of a geographical area in southwest Arabia as well as that of a tribal confederation in power from the 1st cent. BC to ca. AD 525.

row.head: Ḥirta
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/219
row.abstract: Ancient city near the Euphrates to the southeast of present-day al-Najaf. Ḥirta was the capital of the pre-Islamic Arab kingdom of the Lakhmids, who were usually allied with the Sasanians and constantly at war with the Ghassānids, allies of Byzantium, to the west.
row.author: H. Takahashi

row.head: Historiography, Syriac
row.abstract: The beginnings of writing history in Syriac remain unknown, but one may connect it to the existence of notes on various events that were kept in the royal archives of Osrhoene (although there must have been similar archives in other Aramaic-speaking countries, e.g. in Adiabene, we have no information about them).
row.author: W. Witakowski

row.head: Hormizd, Monastery of Rabban
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/168
row.abstract: The Chaldean monastery of Rabban Hormizd, built upon a mountain ridge northeast of Alqosh in northern Iraq, is famous not only for its magnificent location and impressive buildings, but also for its central role in the history of the transmission of E.-Syr. literature and its importance in the struggles between the Chald. Church and the Ch. of E., to which the monastery originally belonged.
row.author: H. L. Murre-van den Berg

row.head: Ḥubeika, Joseph

His earliest publications are under the name Bötticher (Boetticher), the name of his father, which he later replaced by de Lagarde (sometimes Latinized into Lagardius), a name that existed in his mother's family.

An outstanding Semitic scholar, he devoted to Syriac literature only a lesser part of his activity, mainly at the beginning of his career (1910–21) and again later, after having been deprived of his chair at the University of Rome because of his opposiiton to fascism, when he was employed as a consultant for Oriental mss. at the Vatican Library (1931–39), under the patronage of its learned Prefetto, the future Cardinal Eugène Tisserant.

row.head: Malankara Syriac Orthodox Church

row.head: Man of God of Edessa
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/607
row.abstract: This general title is given to the anonymous saintly protagonist of a narrative set in Edessa in the 5th cent. The core original story is found in 5 mss. In this account, the Man of God is the son of rich senatorial parents, living either in Rome or Constantinople.
row.author: R. Doran

row.head: Mani
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/608
row.abstract: Founder of a religious movement (Manichaeism).
row.author: J. W. Childers

row.head: Manna, Yaʿqob Awgen
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/609
row.abstract: Bp. and scholar.
row.author: S. P. Brock and G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Manuscripts
row.abstract: The foundation of Syriac studies is the ms. production of past ages. A body of perhaps ten thousand Syriac mss. survives today.
row.author: J. F. Coakley

row.head: Maphrian
row.abstract: The Syriac word maphryono (mpryn’) literally signifies ‘one who bears fruit’, metaphorically a ‘consecrator’.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Maqdisī, Jeremiah
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/612
row.abstract: He was born in Alqosh and attended the Monastery of Rabban Hormizd in 1864.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Mar Thoma Syrian Church (Malankara)
row.abstract: The Mar Thoma Church is that section of the non-Roman St. Thomas Christians which has undertaken a degree of liturgical and doctrinal reform under the influence of Church of England missionaries in the 19th cent.
row.author: J. R. K. Fenwick

row.head: Mara bar Serapion, Letter of
row.abstract: Mara is the presumed author of a letter in which a father gives lessons of wisdom to his son, from whom he is separated.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Marcian the Monk
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/615
row.abstract: Monastic author (or authors) of uncertain identity (he is unlikely to be the Marcian of Theodoret, Historia Philothea [History of the Monks] 3, as Lebon argued).
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Marcion
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/616
row.abstract: Early Christian thinker, founder of the Marcionites.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Mardin
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/130
row.abstract: City in upper Mesopotamia and important center of Syriac Christianity, especially for the Syr. Orth. Church as the city closest to Dayr al-Zaʿfarān, the seat of the Patr. from 1293 until 1932.
row.author: H. Takahashi

row.head: Mari, Acts of
row.abstract: The Acts of Mari, which date from the late 6th or 7th cent., provide an account of the earliest preaching of the Gospel in the Parthian/ Persian Empire.
row.author: S P. Brock

row.head: Mark the Monk
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/619
row.abstract: Greek monastic author of uncertain identity.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Mark, Monastery of St
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/388
row.abstract: Said to be located on the site of the Last Supper and named after the Evangelist, the monastery is situated on Mount mount Zion in Jerusalem.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Maron
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/621
row.abstract: St. Maron, a charismatic charsimatic hermit who lived in the region of the Orontes River valley toward the end of the 4th cent., is venerated as the Father of the Syr. Maron. Church of Antioch.
row.author: J. P. Amar

row.head: Maronite Church
row.abstract: The Syriac Maronite Church of Antioch is an eastern Catholic community of Syriac Antiochene origin with no Orthodox counterpart.
row.author: J. P. Amar

row.head: Martyrs and persecutions
row.abstract: Times of persecution and of martyrdom fall into four main periods: 1. early 4th cent. (and again under Julian, 361-3), within the Roman Empire (i.e. approximately Turkey, Syria, Lebanon, and Palestine); 2. mid-4th to mid-7th cent., in the Persian (Sasanian) Empire (approximately modern Iraq and Iran); 3. under Arab rule; and 4. under Ottoman rule and in modern times.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Marutha of Maypherqaṭ
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/25
row.abstract: Bp., doctor, and co-convenor of the Synod of Seleucia-Ctesiphon (410).
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Marutha of Tagrit
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/93
row.abstract: Metropolitan of Tagrit.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Mary
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/624
row.abstract: Mary, mother of Jesus, features prominently in all the Syriac liturgical and literary traditions.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Masius, Andreas
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/625
row.abstract: Humanist, early scholar of Syriac. Born in the village of Lennik, near Brussels, Masius studied Hebrew, Greek, and Latin in Louvain. Throughout his life he combined his intellectual curiosity with his diplomatic skills, traveling through Europe, often in the service of ecclesiastical or political authorities.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Masora
row.abstract: Name given by modern scholars to an 8th/9th-cent. compilation in W.-Syr. as well as in E.-Syr. tradition, containing various philological and grammatical materials to serve as a tool for the standardization of orthography and pronunciation of the Syriac language.
row.author: A. Juckel

row.head: Masʿūd of Ṭur ʿAbdin
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/279
row.abstract: Author, monk, and solitary, abbot of the Monastery of the Cross (Dayr al-Ṣalīb) near Ḥaḥ (ca. 1462/3–1480/1), bp. for the Monastery of Mor Quryaqos in Hezza near Zargel and Ḥesno d-Kifo (1480/1) with the name Basil.
row.author: H. G. B. Teule

row.head: Matay, Dayro d-Mor
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/227
row.abstract: Located on the Alfof Mountain, known in Arabic as Jabal Maqlūb, 35 km. northeast of Mosul, the monastery is mostly known by its Arabic name Dayr Mār Mattā.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Maximus
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/628
row.abstract: Notable Greek theologian and author.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Medicine
row.abstract: Syriac Medicine comprises the efforts of the Syriac-speaking communities of the West and the East to avoid disease and cure ailments.
row.author: P. E. Pormann

row.head: Melitene
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/136
row.abstract: City in eastern Anatolia, located near the right bank of the Euphrates and to the north of the main range of the Eastern Taurus.
row.author: H. Takahashi

row.head: Meliton the Philosopher
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/631
row.abstract: Meliton is the presumed author of a short ‘Oration (memrā) before Antoninus Caesar’, preserved in ms. Brit. Libr. Add 14,658, the same ms. which also is our sole witness for the ‘Book of the laws of the countries’ associated with Bardaiṣan and for the ‘Letter of Mara bar Serapion’.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Melkite
row.abstract: Derived from Syriac malka, ‘king, emperor’, the term Melkite can have two different senses, referring to: 1. adherents of the imperial religious policy which, from the time of Justin and Justinian, enforced acceptance of the Council of Chalcedon. 2. adherents of the Catholic patriarchal line (since 1724) of the Chalcedonian Patriarchate of Antioch.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Melkite literature in Syriac
row.abstract: Melkites ceased writing in Syriac around the 9th cent., turning to Arabic instead, though translations into Syriac of Greek monastic literature, and especially of liturgical texts continued to be made for rather longer, and Syriac remained a liturgical language in certain areas of Syria until the 17th cent. when there was a sharp decline in its use, though in a few places it continued into the early 18th cent.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Menander, Syriac sentences of
row.abstract: A collection of Syriac sentences attributed to ‘Menander the Wise’, probably the Greek comedian (d. 292/1 BC) under whose name circulated Greek monostichs (ed. Jaekel), many of which were not original to Menander.
row.author: U. Possekel

row.head: Methodius, Apocalypse of Pseudo-
row.abstract: Influential Apocalyptic work of the late 7th cent.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Michael I Rabo
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/217
row.abstract: Patr. and historian, most notably of a World Chronicle. Michael I Rabo (1126-1199) was a distinguished Patr. and a dominant figure in the intellectual history of the Syr. Orth. Church during the 12th cent.
row.author: D. Weltecke

row.head: Michael II the Younger
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/223
row.abstract: Patr. of the Syr. Orth. Church (1199–1215).
row.author: W. Witakowski

row.head: Michael Badoqa
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/637
row.abstract: Syriac author and exegete; bādoqā (‘scholar’) and mallpānā (‘teacher’) at the School of Nisibis during Ḥenana’s tenure as its head (572-610).
row.author: E. Fiano

row.head: Midyat
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/137
row.abstract: Principal town of Ṭur ʿAbdin, situated at the geographical center of the region where the main east-west road from Mardin to Gozarto (Cizre) and the north-south road from Ḥesno d-Kifo (Hasankeyf) to Nisibis meet.
row.author: H. Takahashi

row.head: Mingana, Alphonse
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/639
row.abstract: He was born in Sharansh al-ʿUlya near Zakho and named Hurmiz.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Moberg, Axel
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/640
row.abstract: Professor of Near-Eastern languages at Lund University, Sweden, 1908–37, and Vice Chancellor of the same university, 1926–36.
row.author: B. Holmberg

row.head: Monasticism
row.abstract: Institutionalized form of religious life, devoted to disciplined ascetic prayer practice.
row.author: S. A. Harvey

row.head: Mosul
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/139
row.abstract: City in the north of Iraq, on the west bank of the Tigris opposite the ruins of ancient Nineveh.
row.author: A. Harrak

row.head: Mubārak, Buṭros
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/643
row.abstract: Born in Batḥa, near Ghosṭa, in Lebanon, Mubārak was sent to the Maronite College in Rome at a very young age, in 1672.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Murad, Michael
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/644
row.abstract: He was born in Mosul.
row.author: G.A. Kiraz

row.head: Mūsā al-Ḥabashī, Dayr Mār
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/228
row.abstract: The Monastery of Moses the Ethiopian is perched on top of a steep, rocky promontory that juts out of a deep gully between two cliffs in the high region south of Nabk.
row.author: E. C. Dodd

row.head: Mushe of Aggel
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/64
row.abstract: Translator of Cyril of Alexandria’s Glaphyra and of the History of Joseph and Aseneth (incorporated into Pseudo-Zacharias’s Ecclesiastical History, I.6).
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Mushe bar Kipho
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/173
row.abstract: Bp. of Beth Raman (north of Tagrit on the Tigris), and writer.
row.author: J. F. Coakley

row.head: Mushe of Mardin
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/646
row.abstract: Priest, scribe, and bp. A native of the village of Qāluq, in the region of Ṣawro, near Mardin, Mushe was sent by Patr. ʿAbdullāh I b. Sṭephanos to Rome, where he arrived with some mss. in or shortly before 1549.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Mushe of Nisibis
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/647
row.abstract: Scribe, abbot of Dayr al-Suryān, collector of mss.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Nagran
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/464
row.abstract: City in S. Arabia (Syr. Nagran, or Negran; Arab. Najrān), and city in Iraq.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Naqqāsheh, Afram
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/649
row.abstract: He was born in Mosul to ʿAbdulaḥad b. Eliās Naqqāsheh and Khāliṣah daughter of Qas Boutros and given the baptismal name Behnam.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Narsai
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/650
row.abstract: Poet and teacher of exegesis at the School of Edessa and at the School of Nisibis ; author of popular verse homilies (memre).
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Nathniel of Sirzor
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/651
row.abstract: Bp. of Sirzor; biblical interpreter.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Nau, François
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/652
row.abstract: Syriac scholar, co-founder of the Patrologia Orientalis.
row.author: F. Briquel-Chatonnet

row.head: Nestorianism
row.abstract: The term Nestorianism refers to the idea, allegedly taught by Nestorius, that in the incarnate Christ the Son of God and the son of Mary represent two separate subjects.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Nestorios of Beth Nuhadra
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/654
row.abstract: From 790 until his death, Nestorios occupied the episcopal see of Beth Nuhadra.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Nestorius
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/655
row.abstract: Bp. of Constantinople from 428 to 431.
row.author: G. A. Bevan

row.head: Nicolaus of Damascus
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/656
row.abstract: Historian and peripatetic philosopher, who served as adviser to Herod the Great (74-4 BC). Excerpts from the Syriac version of his compendium covering Aristotle’s works on natural philosophy and metaphysics (‘On the philosophy of Aristotle’) are preserved in ms. Cambridge, Gg. 2.14 (copied in 15/16th cent.?).
row.author: H. Takahashi

row.head: Nilus the Solitary
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/657
row.abstract: Greek monastic author.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Niʿmatullāh, Ignatius
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/285
row.abstract: Scholar, astronomer, maph. (1555–7) and Patr. (1557–76).
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Nineveh
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/144
row.abstract: A very ancient city in northern Iraq located on the eastern side of the Tigris River, directly across from the medieval and modern city of Mosul.
row.author: J. T. Walker

row.head: Nisibis
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/142
row.abstract: City in Mesopotamia and important center of early Syriac Christianity.
row.author: H. Takahashi

row.head: Nisibis, School of
row.abstract: The School of Nisibis was an E.-Syr. institution of learning founded in part by refugees from the School of Edessa after the latter was forcibly closed by the religious and political authorities in 489, because it had become an exegetical circle of dyophysite Christians whose Antiochene theology was no longer welcome in a Roman Empire split by Christological controversy.
row.author: A. H. Becker

row.head: Nöldeke, Theodor
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/661
row.abstract: German Semitist.
row.author: H. Kaufhold

row.head: Nonos of Nisibis
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/156
row.abstract: Polemicist, scholar, and deacon.
row.author: M. P. Penn

row.head: Nūrī, Athanasios Ignatios
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/662
row.abstract: He was born in Mardin of Niʿmatallāh Nūrī and Katherine daughter of ʿAbdulmasīḥ Tarzi and was given the baptismal name Naṣrallāh.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Nuro, Abrohom
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/663
row.abstract: Educator and modern reformer.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Old Syriac documents
row.abstract: The Syriac language is best known from the large corpus of Christian literature that began to be produced by the 2nd-cent. and continues to be composed until the present day.
row.author: A. M. Butts

row.head: Old Syriac Version
row.abstract: Modern term for the NT versions prior to the Peshitta (excluding the Diatessaron), which includes 1. the ‘Curetonian’ and Sinaitic Gospel mss.; 2. quotations mainly in the writings of Aphrahaṭ, Ephrem, and in the Book of Steps; and 3. the Old Syriac heritage of early Peshitta mss. Frequently the term is restricted to the two mentioned Gospel mss. only.
row.author: A. Juckel

row.head: ʿOnithā
row.abstract: Poetic genre which flourished in late E.-Syr. hymnography.
row.author: A. Mengozzi

row.head: Palimpsests
row.abstract: Palimpsest is the term used for a parchment ms. that has been written on twice (or rarely, more times), where the original script has been erased.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Palladius
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/668
row.abstract: Greek author and bp. of Helenopolis (in Bithynia).
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Papa bar ʿAggai
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/669
row.abstract: Bp. of Seleucia-Ctesiphon.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Papyri, Syriac
row.abstract: Throughout its long history (more than two millennia), the Syriac language has been written on a variety of different mediums.
row.author: A. M. Butts

row.head: Paradise of the Fathers, Book of
row.abstract: The title given, mostly in the Syriac tradition, to a compilation consisting of a collection of stories about monks and solitaries (including Palladius’s ‘Historia Lausiaca’, but also material borrowed from Hieronymus) and a collection of ‘Sayings of the Egyptian Fathers’ (Apophthegmata).
row.author: H. G. B. Teule

row.head: Pawla of Edessa
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/84
row.abstract: Metropolitan of Edessa and translator.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Pawlos of Beth Ukome
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/72
row.abstract: Patr. Pawlos’s name (‘of the house of the black ones’) was rendered in Greek as ‘of the black (ones)’ (Melanos, sing., or Melanōn, plur.).
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Pawlos of Kallinikos
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/47
row.abstract: Bp. of Kallinikos; translator of works of Severus of Anitioch.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Pawlos of Nisibis
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/673
row.abstract: Theologian, biblical commentator, and bp. of Nisibis, for which position he was selected in 544 by Cath. Mar Aba, his former teacher.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Pawlos the Persian
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/674
row.abstract: Itinerant E-Syr. scholar.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Pawlos the Philosopher
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/675
row.abstract: Author of philosophical works.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Pawlos of Tella
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/82
row.abstract: Bp. and translator.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Payne Smith (Mrs. Margoliouth), Jessie
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/676
row.abstract: Syriac scholar and compiler of A Compendious Syriac Dictionary (1902). Daughter of Robert Payne Smith, compiler of the Thesaurus Syriacus, she gained her knowledge of Syriac and of lexicography from her father.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Payne Smith, Robert
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/677
row.abstract: Syriac scholar and compiler of the Thesaurus Syriacus.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Perley, David Barsum
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/678
row.abstract: Assyrian nationalist writer and activist.
row.author: J. F. Coakley

row.head: Peshitta
row.abstract: The name ‘Peshitta’ is used both for the translation of the OT, made in the 2nd cent. on the basis of the Hebrew text, and for a revision of the Old Syriac Version of the NT, which became the standard version around 400.
row.author: R. B. ter Haar Romeny and C. E. Morrison

row.head: Peter the Iberian
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/680
row.abstract: The son of Bosmarios, king of Georgia (Iberia), he was brought up in Constantinople as a political hostage at the court of the Emperor Theodosius II.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Peter of Kallinikos
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/75
row.abstract: Syr. Orth. Patr. of Antioch, theologian, and liturgist.
row.author: L. R. Wickham

row.head: Philoxenos of Mabbug
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/44
row.abstract: Metropolitan bp. of Mabbug (modern Membij/ancient Hierapolis) (485-519), ascetic theologian, christological polemicist, and sponsor of the Philoxenian NT.
row.author: D. A. Michelson

row.head: Physiologus
row.abstract: A collection of short texts, originally written in Greek, concerning natural history (mainly animals).
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: van der Ploeg, Johannes P. M.
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/682
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Poetry
row.abstract: The basic organizing principle of Syriac poetry is syllable (hegyānā) count.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Polykarpos
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/35
row.abstract: Chorepiscopus of the diocese of Mabbug, who was commissioned with the translation of the NT (and parts of the OT) by Philoxenos of Mabbug (the so-called Philoxenian version).
row.author: A. Juckel

row.head: Porphyry
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/684
row.abstract: Greek author and Neoplatonist.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Printing
row.abstract: Syriac printed from wood-cuts can be found in European books as early as 1486, but the first text to be printed from type was in T. Ambrogio’s Introductio in linguam chaldaicam (Pavia, 1539).
row.author: J. F. Coakley

row.head: Proba
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/686
row.abstract: Syriac commentator on Aristotle’s writings on logic.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Proba, metr. of Chalcedon
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/687
row.abstract: Metropolitan of Chalcedon. Most of what is known about this Proba comes from the only extant fragment of Dionysios of Tel-Maḥre’s Chronicle (CSCO 84, 219-24; GT in Abramowski).
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Proclus of Constantinople
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/688
row.abstract: Bp. of Cyzicus and since 434 Patr. of Constantinople.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Psalms, Syriac Apocryphal
row.abstract: The Syriac Apocryphal Psalms are a group of five poetic compositions related to the book of Psalms (ed. Baars).
row.author: A. M. Butts

row.head: Qara
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/161
row.abstract: Town in the Qalamun mountains, Syria, ca. 95 km. northeast of Damascus and less than 20 km. north of Nabk (see Dayr Mār Mūsā al-Ḥabashī), often mentioned as a caravan station between Ḥimṣ and Damascus.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Qarabashī, ʿAbd al-Masīḥ Nuʿmān
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/691
row.abstract: He was born in Qarabash near Diyarbakır (Amid).
row.author: Polycarpus A. Aydin and G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Qaraqosh
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/262
row.abstract: A sizable town located to the east of Mosul, on the same road along which Barṭelle and Karamlish are located.
row.author: A. Harrak

row.head: Qarqaphto, Monastery of
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/229
row.abstract: The Qarqaphto (‘Skull’) Monastery was located near the town of Magdal on the Khabur river southeast of Reshʿayna, in the Jazīra region of Syria.
row.author: J. A. Loopstra

row.head: Qdām w-Bāthar
row.abstract: Book containing parts of the daily offices.
row.author: J. F. Coakley

row.head: Qenneshre, Monastery of
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/230
row.abstract: A W.-Syr. monastery that in its heyday (6th–9th cent.) stood out as a center of Greek study in the Syriac-speaking Near East and which played a key role in the transmission of Greek learning into Syriac.
row.author: J. Tannous

row.head: Qiryo, Yuḥanna
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/696
row.abstract: He was born in Alqosh.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Qiyore of Edessa
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/697
row.abstract: Syriac author.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Qoro, Elias Malke
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/698
row.abstract: Patr. delegate to Malankara.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Qurillona
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/20
row.abstract: Syriac poet.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Quryaqos
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/145
row.abstract: Patr. of Antioch, ordained on 17 Aug. 793 in Ḥarran, died in June or August 817 in Mosul (the sources are not unanimous); he came from Tagrit; before becoming Patr. he had been a monk in the Monastery of Esṭona near Kallinikos.
row.author: W. Witakowski

row.head: Rabbula of Edessa
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/26
row.abstract: Bp. of Edessa (411/2–435/6).
row.author: S. A. Harvey

row.head: Rabbula Gospels
row.abstract: Syriac ms. (now Florence, Bibl. Mediceo-Laurenziana, Pluteus I,56) containing the four Gospels, preceded by an important set of illuminations (f. 1r-14v).
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: al-Rāhib, Elias
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/700
row.abstract: He was born in Shaqlāwa of the Sher family.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Raḥmani, Ignatius Ephrem II
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/701
row.abstract: Patr. (1898-1929), scholar, and liturgist.
row.author: S. P. Brock and G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Renaissance
row.abstract: A term probably first used by A. Baumstark to denote a period in Syriac literature (11th-13th cent.) of great productivity, characterized by a growing acceptance of Arabic science and of Arabic and Muslim cultural and religious patterns.
row.author: H. G. B. Teule

row.head: Reshʿayna
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/172
row.abstract: City on the Khabur, located in the eastern part of ancient Osrhoene and today straddling the Turkish-Syrian border, the Syrian part now bearing the name Raʾs al-ʿAyn and the Turkish part Ceylanpınar (earlier Resülayn).
row.author: H. Takahashi and L. Van Rompay

row.head: Rhétoré, Jacques
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/704
row.abstract: French Dominican missionary, scholar, writer and poet in Sureth.
row.author: A. Mengozzi

row.head: Rhetoric
row.abstract: In the widest sense a term designating the artistic use of language, primarily in speech but secondarily in writing, with the purpose of influencing the hearers or readers.
row.author: J. W. Watt

row.head: Romanos the Melodist
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/706
row.abstract: Byzantine hymnographer and deacon.
row.author: W. L. Petersen

row.head: Saba, Boutros
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/707
row.abstract: He was born in Barṭelle, studied at Sharfeh from 1906, and then at the Syriac Catholic Seminary in Jerusalem.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Sabrishoʿ I
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/708
row.abstract: Cath. (596-604). He originated from Beth Garmai and was born ca. 525.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Sabrishoʿ bar Pawlos
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/709
row.abstract: Author of a hymn for Mid-Lent, preserved in the Ktābā d-Wardā (see Gewargis Warda) and published by Cardahi.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Sachau, Eduard
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/710
row.abstract: German scholar of Arabic, Aramaic, and Syriac.
row.author: H. Kaufhold

row.head: Sahdona (Martyrius)
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/711
row.abstract: Monastic author.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: al-Ṣahyūnī, Jibrā’īl
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/712
row.abstract: Professor of Arabic and Syriac in Rome, Venice, and Paris. Syriac scholar.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Saka, Yaʿqub
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/305
row.abstract: Minor writer, scribe, and educator.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: al-Ṣalīb, Dayr
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/68
row.abstract: Monastery and village in Ṭur ʿAbdin.
row.author: H. Takahashi

row.head: Salmān, Ḥanna
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/714
row.abstract: He was born in Maʿsarteh and joined the Taw Mim Simkath orphanage in Adana.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Salomon, Désiré
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/715
row.abstract: Salomon was born in Tkhuma and grew up in Khosrowa where he was a pupil at the French Lazarist (i.e. Vincentian) Seminary.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz and J. F. Coakley

row.head: Samuel, Athanasios Yeshuʿ
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/716
row.abstract: Bp. of Jerusalem (1947-48), and first bp. of the United States (1957-95).
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Sargis bar Waḥle
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/717
row.abstract: Monk and poet.
row.author: H. G. B. Teule

row.head: Sargis Bḥira
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/718
row.abstract: Sargis Bḥira is the name of a Syriac monk who allegedly met the Prophet Muḥammad and inspired him to begin preaching to the Arabs.
row.author: B. H. Roggema

row.head: Sargis the Stylite
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/81
row.abstract: A ‘Letter’ attributed to ‘Sargis the Stylite of Gusit’ (near Ḥimṣ) ‘against a Jew who argued that God has no son, and that God has not begotten’ is preserved in a single ms. of the 8th/9th cent.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Sauget, Joseph-Marie
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/719
row.abstract: Scriptor in the Vatican Library (1958-88), and author of numerous valuable studies on Syriac and Christian Arabic literature.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Sawma, Abrohom
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/720
row.abstract: He was born in Midyat and joined Taw Mim Simkath in 1919 in Adana where he learned Syriac under Dolabani.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Ṣawma, Rabban
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/721
row.abstract: Ṣawma was a monk of the Ch. of E. who, sometime around 1275, set out from Dadu (also known as Khān Bālīq, i.e. modern Beijing) in his native China with a youngerdisciple, Markos, on a pilgrimage to Jerusalem.
row.author: J. P. Amar

row.head: Sayfo
row.abstract: ‘Sayfo’, or ‘the sword’, is the term now commonly used for the large-scale massacres of the Syriac (as well as the Armenian) inhabitants of eastern Turkey in 1915 and following years, in the course of World War I and its aftermath (another term also used is ‘Firman’, denoting the order to kill the Christian population; also ‘Seferberlik’ denoting mass deportations).
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Scher, Addai
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/723
row.abstract: He was born Asmar Ṣlewa Scher in 1867 in Shaqlāwa near Arbela.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz and S. P. Brock

row.head: Schulthess, Friedrich
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/724
row.abstract: Professor of Semitics; scholar of Syriac, Christian Palestinian Aramaic, and Arabic.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Scribes
row.abstract: In the Greek and Syriac legal documents from Osrhoene dating from the early 240s, it is only in the three Syriac documents that the scribe identifies himself by name (see Old Syriac Documents).
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Script, Syriac
row.abstract: The Syriac script owes its origin to the Aramaic script of the Achaemenid Persian period (539–330 BC) attested to in many documents, especially from Egypt and Palestine (Elephantine, Samaria, etc.).
row.author: J. F. Healey

row.head: Secundus
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/727
row.abstract: Pythagorean philosopher (perhaps fictional) in the time of Hadrian.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Selb, Walter
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/728
row.abstract: Jurist and historian of Law; professor at the University of Vienna.
row.author: H. Kaufhold

row.head: Seleucia-Ctesiphon
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/182
row.abstract: Also known as al-Madāʾin. Located on the Tigris, south of modern Baghdad.
row.author: M. C. Cassis

row.head: Seminary of St. John
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/477
row.abstract: A prestigious Roman Catholic theological seminary in Mosul, Iraq, called Séminaire Syro-Chaldéen St. Jean in French.
row.author: A. Harrak

row.head: Sergios of Reshʿayna
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/49
row.abstract: Translator of Greek medical and philosophical texts into Syriac.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Severos, Commentary of the monk
row.abstract: Collection of biblical commentaries (OT and NT) by Severos, a monk in the Monastery of St. Barbara near Edessa, who completed his work in 861.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Severos bar Mashqo
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/106
row.abstract: Patr. since 667/8. Severos was from Dayro da-Pgimto (see under Reshʿayna).
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Severos Sebokht
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/99
row.abstract: Scholar, astronomer, philosopher, mathematician, Bp. of Qenneshre (city south of Aleppo); or Bp. of the Monastery of Qenneshre on the east bank of the Euphrates.
row.author: G. J. Reinink

row.head: Severus of Antioch
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/51
row.abstract: Patr. of Antioch, theologian, and prolific Greek author.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Sextus, Sentences of
row.abstract: A Greek collection of ethical sayings dating from the 2nd cent., and probably of Christian authorship (though this has been disputed); Sextus, to whom the original collection of 451 sayings is attributed, is otherwise unknown.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Shahdost
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/732
row.abstract: Bp. of Tirhan. According to the ‘Catalogue’ of ʿAbdishoʿ (chap. 111), Shahdost wrote a ‘synodical oration, some letters along with canons, and some short discourses and turgame’.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Shaliṭa, Mar
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/733
row.abstract: Syriac sources count Mar Shaliṭa among the traditional seventy disciples of Mar Awgen
row.author: E. G. Mathews, Jr

row.head: Shalliṭa of Reshʿayna
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/734
row.abstract: Bp. of Reshʿayna and author of liturgical texts.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Shamsi Clan
row.abstract: Sun worshipers who converted to the Syr. Orth. faith around the 6th cent., according to later testimonies.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Ṣharbokht bar Msargis
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/736
row.abstract: Scholar, probably active as a teacher in the theological school and perhaps also in the Christian medical teaching institute (beth mardutā) of Beth Lapaṭ (Gondeshapur) in Khuzistan.
row.author: G. J. Reinink

row.head: Sharfeh
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/232
row.abstract: The name refers to the tip of a height dominating the towns of Darʿūn and Ḥarīṣa, located some 25 km. to the northeast of Beirut.
row.author: A. Harrak

row.head: Shaʿya, Elias
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/738
row.abstract: He was born in Barṭelle in 1895, ordained deacon by Athanasios Tumo Qaṣīr in 1928 and then a priest for Sanjār by Ignatius Eliya III Shakir.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Shemʿon, Eshai
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/739
row.abstract: Patr. Eshai was consecrated as a boy of eleven after the death of his uncle Mar Shemʿon Pawlos.
row.author: J. F. Coakley

row.head: Shemʿon bar Ṣabbaʿe
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/9
row.abstract: Bp. of Seleucia-Ctesiphon and martyr. Shemʿon was probably the immediate successor of Papa bar ʿAggai (d. between 327 and 335), but nothing is known about his tenure as bp. prior to his arrest.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Shemʿon of Rev Ardashir
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/740
row.abstract: Author of a treatise on family and hereditary law; metropolitan bp. Shemʿon wrote his law book in Persian, but it is known to us only in the Syr. translation of an anonymous monk from Beth Qaṭraye.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Shemʿon Shanqlawi
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/741
row.abstract: Author, teacher of Yoḥannan bar Zoʿbi.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Shemʿon d-Ṭaybutheh
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/742
row.abstract: One of the bright representatives of E.-Syr. mysticism.
row.author: G. Kessel

row.head: Shemʿun II, Basileios
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/291
row.abstract: Writer, maph. of Ṭur ʿAbdin (1710–40), and martyr.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Shemʿun of Beth Arsham
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/53
row.abstract: Polemical writer and bp.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Shemʿun of Edessa
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/80
row.abstract: Author of a work on ‘the return [of the Captivity from] Babylon, and on the Weeks of Daniel’, known from a single ms. where he is described as ‘nosok[omos] (infirmarian)... of Edessa’.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Shemʿun Quqoyo
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/37
row.abstract: Author of nine short poems on the Nativity.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Shemʿun the Stylite
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/744
row.abstract: Saint. Born in the village of Sisa near Nicopolis, Shemʿun was the child of Christian parents.
row.author: R. Doran

row.head: Shlemon of Baṣra
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/745
row.abstract: Bp. and writer. Shlemon was the metropolitan bp. of Prat d-Mayshan, or Baṣra, on the banks of the Shatt al-Arab in southern Iraq.
row.author: J. A. Loopstra

row.head: Shubḥalmaran
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/746
row.abstract: Writer on ascetic life and biblical commentator; metropolitan of Beth Garmai, whose see city was Karka d-Beth Slokh, now Kirkuk, to the south of the upper Lesser Zab river, and approx. 170 km. south-east of Mosul and 250 north of Baghdad.
row.author: D. J. Lane

row.head: Siirt
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/188
row.abstract: A city in eastern Turkey, southwest of Lake Van.
row.author: A. Harrak

row.head: Silwanos of Qardu
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/748
row.abstract: Author, or compiler, of two sets of questions and answers appended to the Urmia recension of Theodoros bar Koni’s ‘Scholion’, as well as of some of the additional passages in the body of that recension.
row.author: H. Takahashi

row.head: Sindbad
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/749
row.abstract: The Book of Sindbad the Sage, on the wiles of women, is probably a product of the Late Sasanian Empire (Perry), though others have considered that it is of Indian origin.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Sleepers of Ephesus, Legend of the
row.abstract: The Legend tells about seven (in Syriac most often eight) young Christian men who during the period of the persecution of the Christians by the Roman emperor Decius (249–251) refused to offer sacrifice to pagan gods, and taking advantage of the emperor’s temporary absence from Ephesus, escaped to the mountains outside the city, where they hid in a cave and fell asleep.
row.author: W. Witakowski

row.head: Smith, Agnes and Margaret
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/751 http://syriaca.org/person/752
row.abstract: Independent self-taught scholars.
row.author: S. P. Brock and G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Sobo, Ignatius
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/753
row.abstract: First Patr. of Ṭur ʿAbdin.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Sobo, Malki al-Qas Afram
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/754
row.abstract: He was born in Arbo, Ṭur ʿAbdin.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Sogdian
row.abstract: The Sogdian language belongs to the Eastern subgroup of the Iranian languages.
row.author: I. Yakubovich

row.head: Solomon, Odes of
row.abstract: The Odes of Solomon consist of 42 short lyric poems, of which the Syriac version is preserved almost complete, while Ode 11 is also known in Greek, and five Odes in Coptic (including 1, lost in Syriac).
row.author: M. S. Lattke

row.head: Sophronius
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/757
row.abstract: Patr. of Jerusalem (from 634) and Greek author.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Sṭephanos bar Ṣudayli
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/36
row.abstract: Monk in the early 6th cent. to whom pantheist ideas were attributed; likely author of the ‘Book of the holy Hierotheos’.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Strothmann, Werner
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/758
row.abstract: Protestant theologian; scholar of Syriac and Near-Eastern studies.
row.author: H. Kaufhold

row.head: Sureth
row.abstract: The term Sureth (< surāʾith ‘in Syriac’) refers to a number of North-Eastern Neo-Aramaic dialects spoken by E. Syrians in North Iraq, especially in the villages of the Mosul plain.
row.author: A. Mengozzi

row.head: al-Suryān, Dayr
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/360
row.abstract: Monastery situated halfway between Cairo and Alexandria in the Wadi al-Natrun, ancient Scetis, Egypt.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Symmachus
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/761
row.abstract: Author of a supplement (covering Cant. 6:12 to the end; probably originally in Greek), preserved at the end of the Syriac translation of Gregory of Nyssa’s unfinished ‘Commentary on the Song of Songs’.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Synodicon Orientale
row.abstract: Collection of reports and canons of the synods of the Ch. of E. held between the years 410 and 775/6.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Syriac Catholic Church
row.abstract: The elevation in 1656 of Andrew Akhījān (d. 1677) as Catholic bp. of Aleppo and then as Patr. in 1662 was the first major attempt to create a ‘Syriac Catholic’ branch out of the Syr. Orth. Church of Antioch.
row.author: A. Harrak

row.head: Syriac Conferences
row.abstract: The first international Syriac conference took place in 1972 in Rome under the title ‘Symposium Syriacum’ (papers published in OCA 197, 1974), thus providing the name for succeeding international Syriac conferences, which take place every four years in different locations.
row.author: S. P. Brock and A. M. Butts

row.head: Syriac Language
row.abstract: Syriac, the self-designations of which are suryāyā, ārāmāyā, and urhāyā, is a dialect of the Aramaic language branch, which is itself a member of the larger Semitic language family.
row.author: A. M. Butts

row.head: Syriac Lexicography
row.abstract: Despite widespread translation activity and the use of Syr. in Late Antiquity by numerous non-native speakers, there are no surviving Syr. lexical materials from this early period, with the exception of two 4th-cent. Manichaean Syr.-Coptic glossaries written on wooden boards, found in the kitchen of an abandoned house at Kellis in the Dakhla Oasis of Egypt (Frnazmann and Gardner).
row.author: D. G. K. Taylor

row.head: Syriac Orthodox Church
row.abstract: It is one of the Oriental Orthodox Churches who accept the councils of Nicea, Constantinople, and Ephesus, but reject Chalcedon.
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Syro-Hexapla
row.abstract: A rendering into Syriac of the Septuagint column of Origen’s Hexapla.
row.author: A. G. Salvesen

row.head: Tagrit
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/193
row.abstract: Tagrit is a modern city located on the west bank of the Tigris, almost mid-way between Mosul and Baghdad.
row.author: A. Harrak

row.head: Tappuni, Gabriel
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/770
row.abstract: He was born in Mosul to a Syr. Cath. family on 3 Nov. 1879, and after his studies in the local Seminary of St. John, he was ordained priest in 1903.
row.author: A. Harrak

row.head: Tatian
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/771
row.abstract: Apologist, teacher, composer of the Diatessaron.
row.author: W. L. Petersen

row.head: Taw Mim Simkath
row.abstract: An organization for the support and welfare of Syr. Orth. orphanages and schools, popularly known by the Syriac acronym Taw Mim Simkath (English T.M.S.).
row.author: G. A. Kiraz

row.head: Telkepe
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/197
row.abstract:
Town 15 km. north of Mosul, it is a populous Chald. settlement, seat of a
bishopric bishopric. , with a conspicuous diaspora in Iraq (Mosul, Baghdad, Baṣra, etc.) as well as in the USA, especially in San Diego and Detroit.
row.author: A. Mengozzi

row.head: Tell ʿAda, Monastery of
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/233
row.abstract: The Monastery of Tell ʿAda, also known as the ‘Great Monastery’, is located just over 48 km. from Aleppo; 1500 m. north of the present village of Tell ʿAda.
row.author: J. A. Loopstra

row.head: Testament of Adam
row.abstract: The Testament of Adam is one of a considerable number of ‘apocryphal’ books dealing with Adam; though its roots lie in Jewish traditions, it is definitely a Christian composition, and was probably composed in Syriac, where it is attested in three recensions.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Testament of our Lord Jesus Christ
row.abstract: A collection in two books of church regulations claiming to be from the mouth of Christ and written down by Clement of Rome.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Thābit b. Qurra
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/777
row.abstract: Abū al-Ḥasan Thābit b. Qurra b. Marwān al-Ṣābī al-Ḥarrānī, the most famous of the ‘Ṣābian’ scholars from the Abbasid period, is one of the few non-Christian authors known by name who composed works in Syriac.
row.author: H. Takahashi

row.head: Theano
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/778
row.abstract: Pythagorean philosopher, usually considered to be either the wife or the daughter of Pythagoras (d. 497/6 BC).
row.author: U. Possekel

row.head: Theodora (Empress)
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/779
row.abstract: Raised as a child acrobat in the circus, Theodora married the future emperor Justinian I in 523.
row.author: S. A. Harvey

row.head: Theodore of Mopsuestia
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/780
row.abstract: Bp. of Mopsuestia, biblical commentator, author of theological works and homilies.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Theodoret of Cyrrhus
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/781
row.abstract: Bp., biblical exegete, church historian, hagiographer, and defender of Antiochene Christology against Cyril of Alexandria.
row.author: R. A. Kitchen

row.head: Theodoros Abū Qurra
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/782
row.abstract: Author, bp. of Ḥarran.
row.author: A. M. Butts

row.head: Theodoros bar Koni
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/783
row.abstract: Author, who taught at the exegetical school of Kashkar.
row.author: A. M. Butts

row.head: Theodoros bar Wahbun
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/216
row.abstract: Author and counter-patriarch.
row.author: H. Kaufhold

row.head: Theodosios (patr.)
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/169
row.abstract: Patr. (887-896), author, and physician.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Theodosios of Edessa
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/150
row.abstract: Metropolitan bp. of Edessa, author, and translator.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Theodosius of Alexandria
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/784
row.abstract: Patr. of Alexandria; leader of the Egyptian and Syrian anti-Chalcedonians.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Theodotos of Amid
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/785
row.abstract: Holy man and bp. His Syr. name is written with final ālaph, which has led modern scholars to read ‘Theodota’ or ‘Theodote’.
row.author: J. Tannous

row.head: Theodotus of Ancyra
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/786
row.abstract: Greek author and bp. of Ancyra.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Theophilos of Edessa
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/787
row.abstract: Multifaceted author, historiographer, and translator.
row.author: L. Van Rompay

row.head: Thomas, Acts of
row.abstract: Composed in Syriac probably in the 3rd cent. (provenance unknown, though traditionally placed at Edessa), the Acts of Thomas is one of the most important of the various apocryphal texts associated with Thomas.
row.author: J. W. Childers

row.head: Thomas Christians
row.abstract: Thomas Christians is the term often used for Christians in south-west India (Malabar) belonging to Churches of Syr. tradition, since they trace their origins back to St. Thomas who, according to tradition, arrived in South India in 52.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Timotheos I
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/790
row.abstract: Cath. of the Ch. of E. Timotheos was born in the village of Ḥazza (near Arbela in Iraq).
row.author: D. Bundy

row.head: Timotheos II
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/person/791

row.head: Ṭur ʿAbdin
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/221
row.abstract: Properly speaking, Ṭur ʿAbdin (‘Mountain of the servants’) does not include the whole province of Mardin in Turkey, but only the limestone plateau in the eastern part of it, between the river Tigris and Nisibis.
row.author: A. N. Palmer

row.head: Turfan, Syriac texts from
row.abstract: German excavations (1904–7), conducted near Bulayıq, north of Turfan, brought to light numerous fragmentary mss. evidently from the library of an E.-Syr. monastery.

row.head: Ṭuroyo
row.abstract: Ṭuroyo is the collective name for the various Modern Syriac dialects used in Ṭur ʿAbdin.
row.author: S. P. Brock

row.head: Urmia
row.subject: http://syriaca.org/place/206
row.abstract: Urmia (Urūmiyya, Rīzāya), a city in northwest Iran, west of Lake Urmia, is first mentioned in E.-Syr. sources in 1111, whereas the mentioning of bishops in Azerbaijan (Hoshaʿ of Ganzak in 486, Ḥenanishoʿ in 605), testify to earlier presence of the Ch. of E. in this region.
row.author: H. L. Murre-van den Berg

row.head: Women in the Syriac tradition
row.abstract: Syriac Christianity from the beginning allotted women important positions as widows, deaconesses, and consecrated virgins; these roles were canonically named, ecclesiastically supervised, and granted significant responsibilities by the 3rd cent.

row.abstract: Ancient Chinese city in Shanxi Province. Located at the eastern terminus of the fabled Silk Route, Xi'an served as the capital of unified China periodically from the 11th cent. BC through the Tang Dynasty (AD 618-907).
